Issues.Title: Modifier order issue: variants before arbitrary not selectors fail to apply styles
Issues.Body:
**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?** For example: v3.4.17 **What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?** For example: postcss" 8.5.3, Vite 6.3.5/7.0.0 **What version of Node.js are you using?** For example: v22.11.0 **What browser are you using?** Chrome **What operating system are you using?** macOS **Reproduction URL** https://stackblitz.com/edit/vitejs-vite-tzng15gi?file=index.html,src%2FApp.tsx **Describe your issue** When using Tailwind CSS with custom variants and arbitrary selectors, there's an issue with the order of modifiers affecting whether styles are applied correctly. Specifically, when a variant like `focus-visible:` or `hover:` is placed *before* an arbitrary selector that contains `:not()`, the styles don't get applied. ### Working example: ```html
working
``` ### Non-working examples: ```html
not working
also not working
``` This appears to be related to how the CSS selectors are generated and composed when variants are applied in different orders. The issue occurs with custom variants (like my implementation of `focus-visible`) as well as built-in variants like `hover:`. IntelliSense's hover preview does get it right though: ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b8ecb265-c5ff-46c7-95c6-7ad6d4fac34e) ## Expected behavior Both ordering approaches should work and apply the styles correctly, regardless of whether the variant is placed before or after the arbitrary selector.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Modifier order issue: variants before arbitrary not selectors fail to apply styles" (#18387)

Issues.Title: feat: add Vite 7 support to the @tailwindcss/vite plugin
Issues.Body:
Closes #18381 

* [Changelog for Vite 7.0.0 (2025-06-24)](https://github.com/vitejs/vite/blob/main/packages/vite/CHANGELOG.md#700-2025-06-24)

Starting from Vite 7, Node 18 support will be dropped, which doesn't really affect Tailwind. It might be worth mentioning in the documentation that the recommended minimum Node versions are 20.19 and 22.12.

Vite 7 is only available in ESM format, which is also not an issue.

Vite's browser support aligns with the v4 guidelines:
```
Chrome 87 → 107       (tw: 111)
Edge 88 → 107         (tw: 111)
Firefox 78 → 104      (tw: 128)
Safari 14.0 → 16.0    (tw: 16.4)
```
* [Vite 7 - Browser Support](https://vite.dev/guide/migration.html#default-browser-target-change)
* [Tailwind CSS v4 - Browser Support](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/compatibility#browser-support)

So, at first glance, there's nothing more to do except enabling support for these versions.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat: add Vite 7 support to the @tailwindcss/vite plugin" (#18384)

Issues.Title: `calc-size()` requires two parameters, but Tailwind doesn't work with two arguments
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

`v4.1.6` (problem is also reproducible in the playground using latest version)

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

Webpack 5, React 18, PostCSS plugin

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

`v20.10.0`

**What browser are you using?**

Chrome (other browsers do not support this functionality)

**What operating system are you using?**

macOS and Windows

**Reproduction URL**

https://play.tailwindcss.com/t0kpiVIkMI

**Describe your issue**

The first div uses `h-[calc-size(max-content)]` which emits the correct CSS attribute applied (`height: calc-size(max-content)`) but that is an invalid property value since it requires 2 parameters.

The second div uses `h-[calc-size(max-content, size)]` which should emit the CSS attribute `height: calc-size(max-content, size)` which is a valid CSS attribute value in Chrome but Tailwind emits no class name definition for this property.

~~I'm not sure if I'm doing something wrong syntactically here, or if this behaviour is specific to the `calc-size()` implementation within Tailwind, or with multi-parameter CSS function handling within Tailwind.~~

The third div uses `h-[calc-size(max-content,size)]` which _DOES_ work. Could this indicate that spaces aren't valid within expressions and are always treated as separators for properties?

## References

- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/calc-size#parameters
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`calc-size()` requires two parameters, but Tailwind doesn't work with two arguments" (#18383)

Issues.Title: Angular: Error in PostCSS + tailwind 4 doesn't break the build
Issues.Body:
With Angular and Postcss + Tailwind 4, when I have an error in a css file, it displays a big red error in the logs, but the build continue and is done successfuly.

The expected behavior is it should break the build, so you don't ship bugged CSS. The error seems due to tailwind not reporting correctly the error to postcss.

**Reproduction:**

- create a new angular project with default options.
- npm install tailwindcss @tailwindcss/postcss postcss --force
- create the .postcssrc.json with 
```
{
  "plugins": {
    "@tailwindcss/postcss": {}
  }
}
```
- add the follwing in the css of a component `@reference "not-found.css";`
- npm run build

The error is displayed but the build continue and is successful.

**Version:**

"@tailwindcss/postcss": "4.1.10"
"postcss": "8.5.6"
Angular CLI: 20.0.3
Node: 20.19.2
Package Manager: npm 11.4.1
OS: linux x64
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular: Error in PostCSS + tailwind 4 doesn't break the build" (#18370)

Issues.Title: According to imunifyAV this may contain malware
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

For example: ``` "tailwindcss": "^3.4.0",```

**What build tool (or framework if it abstracts the build tool) are you using?**

For example: ```"vite": "^6.0.11"``` ```"postcss": "^8.4.32"```

**What version of Node.js are you using?**

For example: ```v20.19.0```

**What browser are you using?**

For example: ```Chrome``` ```Safari```

**What operating system are you using?**

For example: ```macOS```

**Reproduction URL**

 - This issue occurs in any Laravel + Tailwind CSS project where server-side builds are run and the server is protected by ImunifyAV malware scanning.

- A minimal reproduction repo is not required here since the issue does not stem from custom project logic but from native Tailwind dependencies downloaded via npm install.

**Describe your issue**

These .node binaries are being flagged by enterprise-grade AV software like ImunifyAV (used on Plesk, CloudLinux, and cPanel-based environments). While we understand these are precompiled performance tools, some transparency or build options would help dev teams avoid security flagging on production servers.

When deploying a Laravel 11 project using Tailwind CSS (via @tailwindcss/oxide) on a production server running ImunifyAV malware scanning, several files in the node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-* directories are repeatedly flagged as malware.

The affected files are native .node binaries such as: 

```node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```

---

 ```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```
 ```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-gnu/tailwindcss-oxide.linux-x64-gnu.node```
```httpdocs/node_modules/@tailwindcss/oxide-linux-x64-musl/oxide.linux-x64-musl.node```

---

🧨 Problem Summary

This isn’t just an issue with Tailwind’s JIT binaries (oxide). Rollup — the JavaScript bundler that many frontend frameworks use (including Vite, which Laravel 11 defaults to) — is also shipping native .node binaries that are being flagged as malware by ImunifyAV.

---

**My Concerns**

Does this make any websites that use this tailwind library to become vulnerable?  ImunifyAV is saying they contain malware. Is it a false positive? On my side I ran the scan about 8 times and it came back with the same thing each time. I have always used tailwind and it would be ashame to have to move away from it due to these security issues.

Issues.Title: Added text-10xl to text-20xl Font Size Utilities
Issues.Body:
Previously, Tailwind CSS supported font sizes only up to text-9xl (8rem), which often required developers to switch to arbitrary values (e.g., text-[10rem]) or extend the theme manually for larger headings and banners. This PR introduces new font size utilities ranging from text-10xl to text-20xl, making it significantly easier and more consistent to scale typography in large design systems without workarounds. ✅ Benefits: Improves developer experience by avoiding arbitrary values. Keeps class naming consistent and predictable. Makes Tailwind more complete for large-scale, responsive design needs (hero sections, headings, etc.). ## Summary ### Issue: Tailwind CSS only supported font sizes up to text-9xl (8rem). For developers needing larger text sizes (e.g., in hero sections or landing pages), this required: Using arbitrary values like text-[10rem], or Extending the Tailwind theme manually. ### Change Introduced: I extended the default fontSize scale by adding new named utilities: text-10xl through text-20xl, with increasing rem values (10rem to 20rem). - This allows users to scale typography in a consistent and semantic way without relying on custom values. - Removes the need to use arbitrary utilities or manually extend the theme. - Keeps the utility-first philosophy intact. - Makes Tailwind more robust and production-ready for large text use cases such as: - Hero headlines - Promo banners - Display typography in dashboards Now developers can simply write text-12xl or text-16xl directly in their markup, without touching tailwind.config.js. ## Test plan ### 🧪 How I Tested the Changes Made the Changes in defaultTheme.js I added the following entries: js '10xl': '10rem', '11xl': '11rem', '12xl': '12rem', '13xl': '13rem', '14xl': '14rem', '15xl': '15rem', '16xl': '16rem', '17xl': '17rem', '18xl': '18rem', '19xl': '19rem', '20xl': '20rem', Built the Package Inside the root of the Tailwind repo: bash pnpm build Linked Locally for Testing I linked the local build to a test React project using: pnpm link --global # Then inside the test project: pnpm link tailwindcss Tested in a React App In the test app, I added:

Massive Text

✅ Verified that the class was generated correctly in the compiled CSS and rendered properly in the browser.

Issues.Title: Tailwind CSS executable missing on Windows 11 for versions above 3.4.17
Issues.Body:
**Description:**
I'm experiencing an issue with Tailwind CSS versions above 3.4.17 on Windows 11. The executable cannot be found by npm/npx after installation.

**Environment:**
OS: Windows 11
Node.js: v22.14.0
npm: 11.4.2
Tailwind CSS: versions above 3.4.17 (works fine on 3.4.17)

**Steps to reproduce:**
```
npm init -y
npm i -D tailwindcss
npx tailwindcss init
```

**Observed behavior:**
When running npx tailwindcss init, I get this error:

```
npm error could not determine executable to run
npm error A complete log of this run can be found in: C:\Users\Joanna\AppData\Local\npm-cache\_logs\2025-06-19T20_34_52_292Z-debug-0.log
```

Additionally, after installing versions above 3.4.17, listing the files in node_modules/.bin does not show the tailwindcss executables. I only see:

```
autoprefixer*      browserslist*      nanoid*      update-browserslist-db*
autoprefixer.cmd   browserslist.cmd   nanoid.cmd   update-browserslist-db.cmd   
autoprefixer.ps1*  browserslist.ps1*  nanoid.ps1*  update-browserslist-db.ps1*
```

**Expected behavior:**
With version 3.4.17, after installing via:
```
npm install -D tailwindcss@3.4.17
```
the executables appear correctly in node_modules/.bin:
```
tailwind*      tailwind.cmd      tailwind.ps1*     tailwindcss*  tailwindcss.cmd  tailwindcss.ps1*
```
and npx tailwindcss init works as expected.

**Additional notes:**

The problem does not occur with Tailwind CSS 3.4.17

[2025-06-19T20_34_52_292Z-debug-0.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/20825530/2025-06-19T20_34_52_292Z-debug-0.log)

.
I have already tried removing node_modules, reinstalling dependencies, and clearing the npm cache. Added the mentioned log for review.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Tailwind CSS executable missing on Windows 11 for versions above 3.4.17" (#18349)

Issues.Title: Fix trailing `)` from interfering with extraction in Clojure keywords
Issues.Body:
## Summary

In a form like, 

```clojure 
(if condition :bg-white :bg-black)
```

`:bg-black` will fail to extract, while `:bg-white` is extracted as expected. This PR fixes this case, implements more comprehensive candidate filtering, and supersedes a previous PR.

Having recently submitted a PR for handling another special case with Clojure keywords (the presence of `:` inside of keywords), I thought it best to invert the previous strategy: Instead of handling special cases one by one, consume keywords according to the Clojure reader spec. Consume nothing else, other than strings.

Because of this, this PR is a tad more invasive rather than additive, for which I apologize. The strategy is this:
- Strings begin with a `"` and ends with an unescaped `"`. Consume everything between these delimiters (existing case).
- Keywords begin with `:`, and end with whitespace, or one out of a small set of specific reserved characters. Everything else is a valid character in a keyword. Consume everything between these delimiters, and apply the class splitting previously contained in the outer loop. My previous special case handling of `:` inside of keywords in #18338 is now redundant (and is removed), as this is a more general solution.
- Discard _everything else_. 

I'm hoping that a strategy that is based on Clojure's definition of strings and keywords will pre-empt any further issues with edge cases.

Closes #18344.

## Test plan
- Added failing tests.
- `cargo test` -> failure
- Added fix
- `cargo test` -> success
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Fix trailing `)` from interfering with extraction in Clojure keywords" (#18345)

Issues.Title: illegal hardware instruction running tailwind since version 4 on Mac
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please provide all of the information requested below. We're a small team and without all of this information it's not possible for us to help and your bug report will be closed. -->

**What version of Tailwind CSS are you using?**

3.4.16 works fine
4.0.0-beta.5 and 4.1.10 both fail with an illegal hardware instruction error


**What operating system are you using?**

For example: macOS sequoia on a 2012 MacBook Pro

**Reproduction URL**

The error is produced by simply running the tailwindcss-macos-x64 binary

**Describe your issue**

I ran into a problem first when testing the latest release candidate of Phoenix LiveView. Projects were failing to compile with a tailwind exited with 132 error. It was suggested on the elixir forums I should test the tailwind binary directly.

I downloaded the latest 3.6.14 release and ran it. It runs fine and shows the usage and options. Then I tested the latest 4.1.10 and it fails to run with an illegal hardware instruction error. I then tested the earliest release of 4 I could find on github and it also failed with an illegal hardware instruction error.

As a sanity check I set up a debian 12 vm on my MacBook Pro and downloaded the 4.1.10 version for linux-x64 and it runs fine in the VM so it seems to be something specific about the way the Mac version is built and not an inherent need for a particular hardware instruction.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "illegal hardware instruction running tailwind since version 4 on Mac" (#18339)

Issues.Title: Track source locations through `@plugin` and `@config`
Issues.Body:
Fixes https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss-forms/issues/182

Inside JS plugins and configs we weren't tracking source location info so using things like `addBase(…)` could result in warnings inside Vite's url rewriting PostCSS plugin because not all declarations had a source location.

The goal here is for calls to `addBase` to generate CSS that points back to the `@plugin` or `@config` that resulted in it being called.
